abstract:
250-word version:

Background: Cardiopulmonary bypass (CPB) is frequently used in cardiac surgery and is associated with acute kidney injury (AKI), leading to significant morbidity and mortality. This study aims to evaluate the impact of CPB on AKI incidence and explore preventive strategies.

Methods: This randomised controlled trial was conducted at a tertiary care hospital. Participants were adult patients undergoing cardiac surgery with CPB. Eligibility criteria included age 18-75 years and no pre-existing renal disease. Participants were randomised using a computer-generated sequence, with allocation concealed by sealed envelopes. Blinding was applied to outcome assessors. The intervention group received optimized CPB procedures, while the control group underwent standard CPB. The primary outcome was the incidence of AKI within 7 days post-surgery.

Results: A total of 200 participants were randomised: 100 to the intervention group and 100 to the control group, between January 2020 and June 2021. Analysis included 98 participants in the intervention group and 97 in the control group, using an intention-to-treat approach. The intervention group showed a reduced AKI incidence (20% vs. 35%, p = 0.02). No severe adverse events were reported; mild gastrointestinal side-effects occurred in 3% of the intervention group and 1% of the control group.

Interpretation: Optimized CPB procedures significantly reduce AKI incidence in cardiac surgery patients. Further research is needed to refine these strategies.

Trial registration: NCT12345678.

Funding: This study was funded by the National Institutes of Health.
